title: Tube Strike Days Away As Offer Rejected
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Mon, Aug 3, 2015, 15:20 BST - UK Markets close in 1 hr 10 mins Tube Strike Days Away As Offer Rejected By (c) Sky News 2015 | Sky News – 15 minutes ago View Photo 

A London Underground strike looks almost certain to go ahead this week after two unions rejected the latest offer. 
ASLEF and Unite said the deal still did not address concerns over pay and conditions on the new night Tube service - slated to begin on 12 September. 
London travellers now face more chaos just weeks after another shutdown - the biggest in over a decade - brought the network to a standstill. 
The proposed walkout by thousands of workers would see no Tube from Wednesday evening and none at all on Thursday. 
Transport for London (TfL) is warning people to travel earlier on Wednesday but said services would be much busier in the hours leading up to the shutdown. 
DLR, London Overground, tram and TfL Rail services are not affected but are also expected to be busier. 
Extra river services and 250 more buses are being readied to help people get around. 
London Underground (LU) said the new offer was not worth more, but had been "reshaped" to address concerns about work-life balance of night Tube workers. 
But ASLEF berated LU over a "complete lack of firm commitments on work-life balance" and said its members wanted "guarantees on the number of weekend rest days they will have". 
It added: "We genuinely regret the disruption this will cause. 
"But the blame for this must rest with the pig headed determination of the Mayor to insist on a September launch instead of allowing more time for a negotiated settlement to be reached." 
First Great Western train services - which operates many services to and from London Paddington - has also announced fresh strikes. 
The RMT union has said action is planned on 23 August, and over the bank holiday weekend - 29 to 31 August. 
The walkout is over concerns around the introduction of new Hitachi (Other OTC: HTHIF - news ) inter-city trains. 
Meanwhile, TfL has also announced a £5.4bn overhaul of four of the capital's oldest tube lines. 
It said the upgrades will bring faster, more frequent and more reliable trains to the Circle, District, Metropolitan and Hammersmith & City lines.
